content:
衛生福利部民國107年7月20日 衛部秘字第1072161286號通知單註銷密等
- 22 -
With regard to (a), taxonomic objectives, the International Centres do not themselves lay down the rules of taxonomy and nomenclature for the enteric bacteria with which they are concerned. They have the more practical task of providing the working materials essential for identification of these bacteria (in accordance with established rules of taxonomy and nomenclature), and of facilitating this work wherever possible.
With regard to (b), epidemiological objectives, the International Centres are not expected to carry out intensive epidemiological studies. Their contributions to such studies and to public health action are made indirectly by concentrating on (a), the taxonomic aspects, and so providing a consistent bacteriological background for the work of the epidemiologists and public health specialists.
A programme of co-ordination of the activities of the International Centres is outlined.
The International Centres work in direct relationship with National Salmonella Centres and National Shigella Centres throughout the world. They assist the National Centres to do their own typing of enteric bacteria, by providing them with standard materials and information. The National Centres should then be in a position to do all their own routine typing, and to prepare the materials for this themselves, sending only special material to the International Centres. Detailed lists are given of the materials supplied by the three International Centres to newly established National Salmonella and National Shigella Centres.
It is suggested that although the International Centres for Salmonella and Escherichia on the one hand and for Shigella on the other, happen to be in widely separated institutions, the National Salmonella and Shigella Centres of a country should, as a general rule, not be housed in separate institutions but in a single one.
Whether or not the National Salmonella and the National Shigella Centres of any country are housed in the same institution, only one of each and not several (i.e. only one National Salmonella Centre and one National Shigella Centre) should be officially recognized for direct relationship with the International Centres. It is a prerogative of the government of each country alone, and not of WHO or the International Centres, to select and appoint the laboratories which are to serve as its National Centres. Staffing of such Centres by expert enteric bacteriologists is essential.
Some indication is given of the training facilities available at the International Centres.
國史饭 Academia Historica
94
